author: M Ratnakar
title: SAI red-faced as AIIMS clears 'overage' Siril Verma
text:
HYDERABAD: In a development that has left the Sports Authority of India (SAI) with egg on its face, shuttler Siril Verma, who was found overage ahead of the Asian Junior Badminton Championships, was cleared by the All India Institute of Medical Sciences (AIIMS). 

Siril and three other girls in the U-17 category - Kalpita Sawant, Bhavya Rishi and Kanika Kanwal - were declared overage by the doctors at the Ram Manohar Lohia Hospital in New Delhi who conducted age determination tests at the behest of SAI last week. 

Siril was certified above 18 years of age hours before the Indian team was to board the flight to Indonesia. Aghast at the report, Siril's parents took him to AIIMS, the country's premier hospital, on Tuesday. 

Dr. Smriti Hari, additional professor of Department of Radiology at AIIMS, certified that Siril's age was estimated to be between 16-18 years. It is learnt that the doctors at AIIMS were surprised at the 'overage' report. 

Like others, Siril's parents too had cried foul before they took their son to AIIMS. They alleged that it was a conspiracy to prevent Siril from participating in the tournament. Siril was the top seed and favourite to win a medal at the Asian meet. 

Similar were the cases of Kalpita Sawant and Bhavya Rishi. Statistical records suggest that their birth certificates are genuine as they showed the periods of their mothers' pregnancy and the dates of delivery. 

According to Nilesh Prabhu, a key member of the parents' body which exposed several age fraud incidents through RTI, Sawant's and Bhavya's age cannot be wrong as both have clear statistical records. 

"When the dates of mother's pregnancy are recorded with a reputed hospital how can the age be wrong? There is a big scam here because the real cheats were cleared," said Prabhu. Stay updated on the go with Times of India News App. Click here to download it for your device.
